questions.text: The following documents are exceptions to oral evidence in court:

options.label: B
options.text: Dying declaration if the victim survived

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Reports of Fingerprint Bureau

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that documents such as reports from the Fingerprint Bureau, chemical examiners, and toxicologists are exceptions to oral evidence in court. These reports provide factual, objective data that do not require oral testimony for interpretation, unlike medical evidence or a surviving victim's dying declaration.

questions.text: During a late-night shift in a district hospital's emergency department, a medical officer is urgently called to attend to a patient with critical injuries from a hit-and-run accident. As the patient's condition deteriorates rapidly, the medical officer realizes the importance of recording the patient's account of the incident, suspecting it might be the patient's dying declaration. Given the urgency of the situation and the legal significance of the patient's statement, which of the following actions aligns best with the protocol for recording a dying declaration in India?

options.label: A
options.text: The medical officer must wait for the presence of the accused and their lawyer before recording the patient's statement.

options.label: B
options.text: The medical officer can record the patient's statement only if the magistrate is present.

options.label: C
options.text: The medical officer is allowed to ask leading questions to quickly gather all necessary information from the patient.

options.label: D
options.text: If the patient unexpectedly recovers, the recorded statement will lose its value

questions.correct_answer: D. If the patient unexpectedly recovers, the recorded statement will lose its value
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) If the patient unexpectedly recovers, the recorded statement will lose its value

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A dying declaration is valid even if recorded by a medical officer or other witnesses in the absence of a magistrate. However, it will lose its value as a dying declaration if the patient recovers. Leading questions should never be asked while recording such a declaration.
  • ➤ dying declaration

questions.text: 32-year-old women married for 5 years was found deceased under suspicious circumstances in a rented apartment in Mumbai. The case has drawn significant media attention, and there is pressure on authorities to conduct a thorough investigation. According to the Indian legal process, which type of inquest will be done?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Magistrate inquest

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspicious deaths occurring within 7 years of marriage in India, particularly when dowry-related harassment is suspected, a magistrate inquest is required by law to ensure a thorough investigation. This process is meant to prevent foul play and ensure justice in cases of dowry deaths.
  • ➤ magistrate inquest

questions.text: In which of the below circumstances does Dying declaration become invalid?

options.label: A
options.text: Dying declaration recorded by a staff nurse

options.label: C
options.text: The victim died immediately after giving the statement

options.label: D
options.text: Dying declaration was recorded by police officer

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The victim was intoxicated

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A dying declaration must be made by a person in a sound mental state to be considered valid. If the victim is intoxicated or otherwise impaired, the reliability of their statement is compromised, rendering the dying declaration invalid.

questions.text: Dr. Anand, a distinguished orthopaedic surgeon, has been invited to give expert testimony in a complicated case where a fellow surgeon is accused of negligence during a hip arthroplasty. In the course of preparing for his deposition, Dr. Anand revisits legal terminologies pertinent to his testimony, particularly concerning witness compensation known as 'conduct money'. Which of the following assertions about 'conduct money' is accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: It is paid by the defendant.

options.label: B
options.text: It is paid after the witness is done in the court.

options.label: C
options.text: The amount is decided by the plaintiff.

options.label: D
options.text: It is paid by the Plaintiff.

questions.correct_answer: D. It is paid by the Plaintiff.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conduct money is a legal obligation paid by the plaintiff (or summoning party) to ensure that witnesses appear in court without financial burden. It is provided in advance of the court appearance.

questions.text: Dr. Singh, a cardiologist in New Delhi, is under investigation after several complaints from patients regarding his prescription practices, which allegedly violate the nationally recognized medical code of ethics. He is accused of overprescribing medications in exchange for incentives from a pharmaceutical company. In the context of medical regulation in India, to which authority can Dr singh appeal if he is punished by state medical council?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Central Health Ministry

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases where a doctor is punished by the State Medical Council for infamous conduct, they must appeal to the Central Health Ministry , which then consults the National Medical Commission for further advice. The MCI no longer exists as it has been replaced by the NMC.
  • ➤ State Medical Council
  • ➤ Central Health Ministry
  • ➤ National Medical Commission

questions.text: A neurosurgeon at a private hospital has a standing agreement with a referring primary care physician. For every patient referred to the neurosurgeon, the primary care physician receives an appreciation letter and details of all the follow up from the neurosurgeon. What can be the punishment for this?

options.label: C
options.text: Filing an FIR against the patient for not paying the fee

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) No punishment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In medical practice, providing appreciation letters and follow-up details to a referring physician does not violate ethical guidelines, as long as there is no financial incentive or commission involved. Therefore, no punishment is applicable in this scenario.
  • ➤ providing appreciation letters and follow-up details

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy Gautam is accused of causing a grievous hurt to an elderly man in his neighborhood. The case of Gautam will be tried in a juvenile court which has a Juvenile justice board. Which of the following is true with respect to composition of juvenile justice board?

options.label: A
options.text: Three Social workers of which two must be women

options.label: C
options.text: Judicial Magistrate of first class who must be a woman

questions.correct_answer: B. Judicial Magistrate of first class
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Judicial Magistrate of first class

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Juvenile Justice Board is composed of a Judicial Magistrate of the first class and two social workers , one of whom must be a woman. The magistrate can be of any gender, and this board ensures that juvenile cases are handled with sensitivity towards the rights and welfare of the minor.
  • ➤ Juvenile Justice Board
  • ➤ Judicial Magistrate of the first class
  • ➤ two social workers

questions.text: In a lecture on the professional conduct of healthcare workers, a forensic expert is explaining the concepts of medical etiquette and medical ethics to medical students. The expert emphasizes the differences between these two concepts and asks the students to identify the correct description of medical etiquette. What does medical ethics specifically refer to?

options.label: B
options.text: Customs of courtesy among members of the same profession

options.label: C
options.text: Moral principles in dealings with patients and the state

options.label: D
options.text: Having reasonable skill in treating patients

questions.correct_answer: C. Moral principles in dealings with patients and the state
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Moral principles in dealings with patients and the state

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Medical ethics involves the moral principles guiding healthcare professionals' conduct with patients, colleagues, and society. It differs from medical etiquette, which deals with courtesy among professionals, and from laws, which are enforceable rules.
  • ➤ Medical ethics
  • ➤ moral principles

questions.text: A patient is brought into the emergency room after a severe car accident. The patient is unconscious and in critical condition, with multiple injuries. In this situation, the healthcare team may need to perform various surgical procedures, such as: Emergency surgery to stop internal bleeding. Orthopedic surgery to repair broken bones. Neurosurgery to relieve pressure on the brain. Plastic surgery to address facial injuries. Thoracic surgery to treat lung injuries. The healthcare team explains all the risks and different types of surgeries that will be required for multiple injuries. This is a type of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Informed consent

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Informed consent is necessary when a patient (or their legal representative) is provided with a full explanation of the procedures, risks, benefits, and alternatives, allowing them to make a knowledgeable decision about the care provided. In emergency situations where a patient cannot provide consent, their legal surrogate must be approached to give informed consent.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of hypertension and diabetes is scheduled for an elective hernia repair. Upon admission, he is presented with a document to sign, which consents to the surgery and any additional necessary procedures that may be discovered intraoperatively. This type of consent implies that the patient agrees to all aspects of care, including those not specifically mentioned in the document, provided they are in the course of standard treatment. How is this form of consent best described?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Blanket consent

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Blanket consent is a broad consent that covers not only the primary procedure but also any additional procedures that might be necessary. It is common in situations where specific future needs cannot be fully anticipated, allowing healthcare providers flexibility to address unforeseen medical issues that arise during the course of treatment.
  • ➤ Blanket consent

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the typical eruption ages for different permanent teeth, such as:
  • ➤ First molar : 6-7 years Lateral incisor : 8-9 years Canine : 11-12 years Third molar : 17-25 years
  • ➤ First molar : 6-7 years
  • ➤ First molar
  • ➤ Lateral incisor : 8-9 years
  • ➤ Lateral incisor
  • ➤ Canine : 11-12 years
  • ➤ Canine
  • ➤ Third molar : 17-25 years
  • ➤ Third molar

questions.text: Number of temporary teeth at 5 years:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 20

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ At the age of 2-6 years , children typically have 20 temporary teeth and 0 permanent teeth . Temporary teeth begin to fall out and be replaced by permanent teeth starting around the age of 6.
  • ➤ 2-6 years
  • ➤ 20 temporary teeth
  • ➤ 0 permanent teeth

questions.text: Which of the following feature is related to the mandible of female?
questions.correct_answer: A. Angle of ramus- More obtuse
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Angle of ramus- More obtuse

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The female mandible typically exhibits a more obtuse angle at the ramus compared to the male mandible, which has sharper angles and more prominent features
  • ➤ female mandible
  • ➤ more obtuse angle

questions.text: A skull was recovered from a forest. According to inquest papers, woman had gone missing after a fight with her boyfriend a month back. The skull was sent to the forensic research lab. Which of the following would identify it as a female skull? Prominent external occipital protuberance Heavy cheek bones Square orbits Large mastoid
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Male skulls typically exhibit prominent, heavy, square, and large features , whereas female skulls are characterized by smoother and more rounded structures, with exceptions like prominent parietal and frontal eminences and rounder orbits .
  • ➤ prominent, heavy, square, and large features
  • ➤ smoother and more rounded
  • ➤ parietal and frontal eminences
  • ➤ rounder orbits

questions.text: A forensic anthropologist is examining a set of skeletal remains discovered at an archaeological site. The mandible is relatively well preserved. The focus is on determining the sex of the individual based on the mandible. Which of the following features will be found in male mandible as compared to female mandible?

options.label: A
options.text: Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

options.label: B
options.text: Round Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

options.label: C
options.text: Square Chin, more obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

options.label: D
options.text: Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, smaller body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

questions.correct_answer: A. Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The male mandible is characterized by a square chin , less obtuse angle , greater body height at the symphysis , and greater breadth of the ascending ramus . These features are important markers for sex determination in forensic anthropology.
  • ➤ male mandible
  • ➤ square chin
  • ➤ less obtuse angle
  • ➤ greater body height at the symphysis
  • ➤ greater breadth of the ascending ramus

questions.text: A girl runs away from home with her boyfriend and they get married. In court, she says that she is a major. Identify the age of the girl from the Xray of her pelvis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) > 21 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In age estimation using pelvic X-rays, the fusion of bones like the ischial tuberosity indicates that the individual is over 21 years old. Bone fusion timelines are critical in forensic anthropology for determining age, especially in legal cases concerning the age of majority.
  • ➤ ischial tuberosity
  • ➤ 21 years

questions.text: While performing the autopsy of a new-born, the forensic specialist noticed that the diaphragm is at a lower level. What is the inference from this finding?

options.label: A
options.text: The baby had phrenic nerve damage

options.label: B
options.text: The baby had not respired prior to death

options.label: C
options.text: The baby had respired prior to death

options.label: D
options.text: Nothing significant can be inferred from this finding

questions.correct_answer: C. The baby had respired prior to death
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The baby had respired prior to death

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In forensic autopsies of newborns, the position of the diaphragm can help determine if respiration occurred prior to death. A diaphragm at a lower level (6th to 7th rib) suggests the baby had respired, while a higher diaphragm (4th to 5th rib) indicates the baby had not taken any breaths.

questions.text: What type of smell is produced by the decomposed body from the given image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Odorless

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In forensic pathology, mummification results in a body that is shrunken, brown, and odorless due to rapid dehydration. This is in contrast to other forms of decomposition that produce strong, offensive odors due to bacterial activity.

questions.text: Time since death can be known by all of the following except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Both A and B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rigor mortis undergoes predictable sequential changes, making it useful for estimating time since death. Cadaveric spasm and heat stiffening occur under specific conditions without any sequential progression, and thus cannot be used for this purpose.
  • ➤ Rigor mortis
  • ➤ Cadaveric spasm
  • ➤ heat stiffening

questions.text: In a forensic investigation involving the sudden death of an individual, the autopsy results reveal no signs of trauma, toxicological substances, or pathological conditions. The cause of death remains undetermined despite a thorough gross as well as microscopic examination. What term is commonly used to describe this outcome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Negative autopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A negative autopsy occurs when no cause of death can be determined after both gross and microscopic examination. It is important to differentiate it from an obscure autopsy , where the cause of death may be identified through microscopic examination after an inconclusive gross examination.
  • ➤ negative autopsy
  • ➤ obscure autopsy

questions.text: A forensic investigator is examining a series of bruises on a victim's body. To determine whether these bruises are artificial or true bruises, which of the following characteristics would be most useful to assess?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Color changes over time

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ True bruises follow a predictable pattern of color changes (red to blue/purple to green to yellow) over time as they heal, while artificial bruises do not undergo such changes. This makes color changes over time the most useful characteristic for forensic investigators when distinguishing between the two.
  • ➤ color changes over time

questions.text: Identify the type of wound from the image:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Defense wounds

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Defense wounds occur when an individual tries to protect themselves from an assault, typically resulting in injuries to the hands and forearms. These wounds can be on both anterior and posterior sides of the body parts involved in defense, unlike hesitation cuts, which are usually associated with self-inflicted injuries in suicide attempts.
  • ➤ Defense wounds

questions.text: Fish tailing is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Stab wound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fish tailing is a feature seen in stab wounds caused by a single-edged knife . It results in a wedge-shaped or teardrop appearance at the exit point of the blade, distinguishing it from other types of wounds. This pattern is different from tailing seen in incised wounds, which refers to the gradual shallowing of a wound.
  • ➤ Fish tailing
  • ➤ single-edged knife
  • ➤ tailing

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes Marshall’s triad in relation to explosive injuries?

options.label: A
options.text: Marshall's triad consists of burns, fractures, and internal bleeding.

options.label: B
options.text: Marshall's triad includes fractures, dislocations, and bone bruises.

options.label: C
options.text: Marshall's triad refers to bruises, abrasions, and puncture lacerations.

options.label: D
options.text: Marshall's triad consists of head trauma, chest trauma, and abdominal trauma.

questions.correct_answer: C. Marshall's triad refers to bruises, abrasions, and puncture lacerations.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Marshall's triad refers to bruises, abrasions, and puncture lacerations.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Marshall's triad is associated with secondary blast injuries and includes bruises, abrasions, and puncture lacerations . These are commonly caused by flying debris or shrapnel in an explosion and are a major cause of death in bomb blast injuries.
  • ➤ Marshall's triad
  • ➤ secondary blast injuries
  • ➤ bruises, abrasions, and puncture lacerations

questions.text: A gunshot case brought for autopsy shows an entry wound with inverted margins and the wound is surrounded by blackening and tattooing. Singed burnt hair was noted. What is the range of the weapon?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Close contact

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A close contact gunshot wound typically shows inverted wound margins , blackening , tattooing , and singeing of hair , due to the proximity of the muzzle when the gun is fired. These features help distinguish it from intermediate and distant range wounds.
  • ➤ close contact
  • ➤ inverted wound margins
  • ➤ blackening
  • ➤ tattooing
  • ➤ singeing of hair
  • ➤ intermediate
  • ➤ distant range

questions.text: The post-mortem examination of a body shows transverse intimal tears on the carotid artery as below. What could be the most probable cause of death?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hanging

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amussat's sign —transverse intimal tears of the carotid artery—is a classic finding in cases of hanging . It results from the stretching of the arteries due to the upward pull of the ligature, distinguishing it from other forms of neck trauma such as strangulation or throttling.
  • ➤ Amussat's sign
  • ➤ hanging

questions.text: A 24-year-old man was found deceased in his living room, suspended by a rope from the ceiling fan. The knot was tied to the right side of his neck. The scene was secured and examined by a forensic expert from the local medical college, who noted several findings consistent with hanging. The body showed signs of lividity in the lower extremities, and there was noticeable constriction around the neck caused by the ligature. During the examination, the forensic expert observed a distinctive pattern of salivary staining. Based on the positioning of the knot and the principles of forensic medicine, where would the dribbling of saliva most likely be found in this case of atypical hanging?

options.label: A
options.text: Towards the site of the knot

options.label: B
options.text: Opposite the site of the knot

options.label: C
options.text: At both angles of the mouth

questions.correct_answer: B. Opposite the site of the knot
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Opposite the site of the knot

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of hanging , saliva dribbles from the side opposite the ligature knot due to the obstruction of salivary glands on the side where the knot is positioned. This is an important forensic finding that helps confirm the positioning of the ligature and the circumstances of the hanging.
  • ➤ hanging
  • ➤ side opposite

questions.text: A dead body is brought for autopsy. On examination of neck, a ligature that was present obliquely, and above the level of the thyroid was seen. Subcutaneous tissue under the mark was white and glistening. What is the cause of death?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hanging

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of hanging, the ligature mark is oblique and located above the level of the thyroid, with white and glistening subcutaneous tissue under the mark, distinguishing it from other forms of neck compression like strangulation or throttling.

questions.text: In a gripping episode of a forensic investigation TV series, the protagonist, a seasoned forensic expert, is called to a picturesque but remote lakeside campsite where a tragic incident occurred. A young camper was found unresponsive in the shallow waters near the shore early in the morning. Initial suspicions pointed towards an accidental drowning, but the expert's keen observations suggest there might be more to the story. As the investigation unfolds, the forensic expert explains the critical nuances of freshwater drowning to the investigative team, focusing on the physiological effects that could lead to fatal outcomes. The team is particularly interested in understanding the mechanism behind the sudden cardiac arrest observed in the victim. What is the most likely cause of ventricular fibrillation in this case of freshwater drowning?

options.label: A
options.text: Total asphyxia induced by the panic and struggle in water

options.label: B
options.text: Cold water shock leading to involuntary laryngeal spasm

options.label: C
options.text: Rapid fluid shifts causing blood thickening and clot formation

options.label: D
options.text: Hemodilution from absorbed freshwater, leading to an electrolyte imbalance

questions.correct_answer: D. Hemodilution from absorbed freshwater, leading to an electrolyte imbalance
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hemodilution from absorbed freshwater, leading to an electrolyte imbalance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of freshwater drowning , the water is hypotonic and causes rapid absorption into the bloodstream, leading to hemodilution and electrolyte imbalances , particularly hyperkalemia . This electrolyte disturbance triggers ventricular fibrillation , resulting in sudden cardiac arrest and death.
  • ➤ freshwater drowning
  • ➤ hemodilution
  • ➤ electrolyte imbalances
  • ➤ hyperkalemia
  • ➤ ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: An autopsy was performed on a woman who was reportedly discovered near a village lake. Among the listed factors, which one indicate drowning prior to death:

options.label: C
options.text: Large amount of fine, white leathery foam around mouth, nostrils and in airway

questions.correct_answer: C. Large amount of fine, white leathery foam around mouth, nostrils and in airway
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Large amount of fine, white leathery foam around mouth, nostrils and in airway

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fine, white foam around the mouth, nostrils, and airway is the most definitive and visual sign of antemortem drowning , making it the best answer in this case. Other findings, like water in the stomach, washerwoman’s hands, or the results of Gettler’s test, may provide additional clues but are not as conclusive on their own.
  • ➤ Fine, white foam
  • ➤ antemortem drowning

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about freshwater drowning:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypovolemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In freshwater drowning , hyperkalemia, hemolysis, and ventricular fibrillation are the key physiological changes due to rapid fluid absorption into the blood. Hypovolemia , which is associated with saltwater drowning, does not occur in freshwater drowning.
  • ➤ freshwater drowning
  • ➤ Hypovolemia

questions.text: Identify the gestational age of the fetus if the Crown Rump Length is 21 cm. Both testes are seen near the external inguinal ring. The gestational age of the fetus will be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 7 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ By 7 months gestational age, both testes are found near the external inguinal ring . The Crown Rump Length (CRL) of 21 cm also supports a gestational age of 7 months .
  • ➤ 7 months
  • ➤ external inguinal ring
  • ➤ Crown Rump Length (CRL)
  • ➤ 7 months

questions.text: Dead Body of fetus was found submerged in water by a local fisherman. The crown heel length was found to be 25 cm, and length of lower limbs was 10 cm. Few hairs were present on his body and ossification center of calcaneum was present. Approximate age of the fetus is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 5 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ At 5 months gestational age, the Crown Heel Length (CHL) is approximately 25 cm , and developmental features such as ossification centers in the calcaneum and some hair growth are evident.
  • ➤ 5 months
  • ➤ Crown Heel Length (CHL)
  • ➤ 25 cm
  • ➤ ossification centers in the calcaneum
  • ➤ some hair growth

questions.text: False -ve hydrostatic test in live born fetus is for:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Atelectasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A false negative hydrostatic test can occur in cases of atelectasis , where the lungs do not fully expand, causing them to sink even if the baby had breathed. In contrast, false positives are seen in cases of putrefaction or artificial respiration .
  • ➤ false negative hydrostatic test
  • ➤ atelectasis
  • ➤ false positives
  • ➤ putrefaction
  • ➤ artificial respiration

questions.text: A dead born foetus does not have:

options.label: C
options.text: Rigor mortis if gestational age is < 7 months

questions.correct_answer: C. Rigor mortis if gestational age is < 7 months
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rigor mortis if gestational age is < 7 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A dead born fetus does not develop rigor mortis if its gestational age is less than 7 months , due to insufficient muscle development. Other findings like overcrowding of ribs or mummification may occur depending on individual circumstances but are not universally absent.
  • ➤ dead born fetus
  • ➤ rigor mortis
  • ➤ 7 months

questions.text: A baby is still born in the hospital, but still has signs of respiration. Which is true in this context?

options.label: A
options.text: This might be a case vagitus vaginalis

options.label: B
options.text: This might be a case of vagitus uterinus

options.label: C
options.text: Can occur due to forceps delivery

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Both A and B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vagitus vaginalis and vagitus uterinus describe situations where a baby breathes or cries while still in the birth canal or uterus, respectively. These can result in signs of respiration being present in a baby that is stillborn , meaning it was not alive after delivery.
  • ➤ Vagitus vaginalis
  • ➤ vagitus uterinus
  • ➤ stillborn

questions.text: Identify the true statement from the following about battered baby syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Skull Fractures of various ages are seen

options.label: B
options.text: It occurs due to the tendency of a child to fall repeatedly

options.label: C
options.text: Rib fractures are suggestive of battered baby syndrome

options.label: D
options.text: Shot gun wounds are commonly seen

questions.correct_answer: C. Rib fractures are suggestive of battered baby syndrome
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rib fractures are suggestive of battered baby syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rib fractures and metaphyseal fractures of long bones are characteristic of battered baby syndrome . These injuries, along with subdural hemorrhage and intraocular bleeding, are suggestive of abuse, especially in cases of shaken baby syndrome .
  • ➤ Rib fractures
  • ➤ metaphyseal fractures of long bones
  • ➤ battered baby syndrome
  • ➤ shaken baby syndrome

questions.text: Police officers found a completely burnt dead body of a person in a forest. They suspect that someone might have killed him and later burnt the dead body to avoid identification. Image of victim is shown below. This is suggestive of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Either A or B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Heat ruptures occur due to the contraction of skin exposed to intense heat, leading to splits or tears that resemble lacerations. These can occur in both antemortem and postmortem burns , and they are differentiated from mechanical trauma by the absence of bleeding.
  • ➤ Heat ruptures
  • ➤ antemortem
  • ➤ postmortem burns

questions.text: Pugilistic attitude is due to:

options.label: A
options.text: Intense heat when body temperature is > 65° C

questions.correct_answer: A. Intense heat when body temperature is > 65° C
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intense heat when body temperature is > 65° C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pugilistic attitude (boxer's attitude) occurs due to intense heat leading to protein coagulation . This results in stiffening of muscles, and the body takes on a flexed posture. ATP depletion is related to rigor mortis and not heat stiffening.
  • ➤ Pugilistic attitude
  • ➤ intense heat
  • ➤ protein coagulation
  • ➤ rigor mortis

questions.text: Characteristic of Joule burn include all except?

options.label: B
options.text: Joule burn is not hyperaemic or only little bit hyperaemic

options.label: C
options.text: Pale raised skin at the margins

options.label: D
options.text: Can be seen at places other than electric contact point

questions.correct_answer: D. Can be seen at places other than electric contact point
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Can be seen at places other than electric contact point

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Joule burns are localized to electrical contact points and present with round or oval, shallow craters and raised, pale margins . They typically show minimal hyperemia and are not found in places where there was no electrical contact.
  • ➤ Joule burns
  • ➤ electrical contact points
  • ➤ round or oval, shallow craters
  • ➤ raised, pale margins
  • ➤ minimal hyperemia

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who was working in the fields all day, collapsed on a hot summer afternoon. His skin was dry and hot, face was flushed, pulse was fast and thready. Which of the following symptoms are least likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sweating

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In heat stroke , the body temperature rises to dangerous levels, and sweating is absent due to thermoregulatory failure. The skin becomes dry and hot , and the patient may collapse due to severe hyperthermia, hypotension, and other systemic effects.
  • ➤ heat stroke
  • ➤ sweating is absent
  • ➤ dry
  • ➤ hot

questions.text: A man who was involved in a bomb blast at a railway station was brought to the hospital with rupture of tympanic membrane. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for these injuries?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) High pressure wave

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary blast injuries are caused by the high-pressure wave generated by an explosion and typically affect air-filled structures like the tympanic membrane, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract. Tympanic membrane rupture is a hallmark of primary blast injury.
  • ➤ Primary blast injuries
  • ➤ high-pressure wave

questions.text: A concerned mother takes her daughter of 14 years age who was complaining of pain in the private parts to a gynecologist. On eliciting history, the girl admits she had consensual sexual intercourse with a neighbor. She is 21 weeks pregnant. Which one is true Take a vaginal Swab MTP cannot be done unless serious congenital anomaly is found Consent of medical board required for MTP No need to inform the police if the victim and mother don’t wish to file a police complaint
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None are true

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases involving minors, any sexual activity is legally classified as rape regardless of consent. Forensic evidence is typically only useful within a short window after the incident. MTP can be performed without a medical board’s consent in cases of rape up to 24 weeks of gestation, and it is mandatory to inform the police.
  • ➤ rape
  • ➤ MTP
  • ➤ 24 weeks

questions.text: A 20-year-old unmarried girl was brought to the OPD. Genital examination revealed the findings as given below. Labia majora - separated Labia minora- flabby Old ruptured hymen Deep, roomy, dilated and capacious with less rugosed wall What is true about this girl from the options below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Not a virgin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The findings of separated labia majora , flabby labia minora , and a ruptured hymen are consistent with someone who is not a virgin . These changes are typically seen in individuals who are habitual to sexual intercourse.
  • ➤ separated labia majora
  • ➤ flabby labia minora
  • ➤ ruptured hymen
  • ➤ not a virgin

questions.text: A 25-year-old man was arrested for sitting naked on a park bench. On police interrogation he was found to be delirious. Which sexual offence can he be held responsible for?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For behavior to be classified as a sexual offense (such as exhibitionism), it must be done with the intention of sexual gratification . In cases where the person is suffering from a mental illness (such as delirium), their actions are not considered a sexual offense.
  • ➤ sexual offense
  • ➤ intention of sexual gratification

questions.text: Police officer brings a 15-year-old male child to doctor for medical examination. Mother of the child gives the history that his uncle has been threatening and sexual assaulting him for past 2 years, which she came to know now and complained the police. After doing the complete examination, doctor examines the anus, which shows features as in the picture below. This is suggestive of?
questions.explanation: Ans. D. None of the above

questions.text: A 20-year-old girl, is brought by a lady police sub-inspector, alleging a history of sexual violence that occurred few months back. Now the girl is 25 weeks pregnant. Which statement is incorrect as the next course of action?

options.label: C
options.text: Consent of a legal guardian is not mandatory

options.label: D
options.text: MTP cannot be performed unless there are serious congenital abnormalities

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Preserve clothing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of sexual assault reported months after the incident, preserving clothing is no longer necessary. Instead, the focus should be on taking a detailed history, ensuring the patient's consent is obtained, and considering the legal and medical provisions for handling a pregnancy resulting from sexual violence.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl, is brought by a lady police sub-inspector to the doctor, alleging a history of sexual violence that occurred in the morning same day. Which statement is incorrect as the next course of action by the doctor?

options.label: C
options.text: Consent of a legal guardian is not mandatory to give the medical treatment for injuries to the victim.

options.label: D
options.text: Consent of victim is sufficient, and that of legal guardian is not required for MTP if the girl is found to be pregnant at a later stage

questions.correct_answer: D. Consent of victim is sufficient, and that of legal guardian is not required for MTP if the girl is found to be pregnant at a later stage
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Consent of victim is sufficient, and that of legal guardian is not required for MTP if the girl is found to be pregnant at a later stage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For girls under 18 years of age , the consent of a legal guardian is required for MTP . However, for general medical treatment (e.g., treating injuries), a girl over 12 years can give consent on her own.
  • ➤ under 18 years of age
  • ➤ legal guardian
  • ➤ MTP

questions.text: A mother delivers twins on same day, but with significantly different development and very different features. On DNA testing, only one of the twins matches the husband. What could be the cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Superfetation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Superfetation is a rare condition where two pregnancies occur in different menstrual cycles, leading to twins with different developmental stages and possibly different fathers. In contrast, superfecundation occurs within the same cycle and usually results in similar development, even if different fathers are involved.
  • ➤ Superfetation
  • ➤ different developmental stages
  • ➤ superfecundation

questions.text: A rape victim is examined in a hospital and a specimen from her vagina is subjected to staining by 10% HCl, potassium iodide, iodine and water. Dark brown rhombic shaped crystals appear immediately. Which confirmatory test should be done, if the accused is azoospermic?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of azoospermia , where no sperm cells are present, the acid phosphatase test is a useful confirmatory test for the presence of seminal fluid. This test detects the enzyme acid phosphatase, which is abundant in semen even in the absence of sperm.
  • ➤ azoospermia
  • ➤ acid phosphatase test

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is found unresponsive in his apartment with multiple bloodstains on his clothing. The first responders to the scene need to determine whether the bloodstains are recent or if some might have been present for a longer period. Which method is not good in in older stains on the clothing?

options.label: D
options.text: Age of stain has little effect on detection accuracy

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Benzidine test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For detecting older bloodstains , methods like spectroscopy and the Takayama test are more reliable. Benzidine tests are less effective for older stains due to the degradation of hemoglobin over time.
  • ➤ older bloodstains
  • ➤ spectroscopy
  • ➤ Takayama test
  • ➤ Benzidine tests

questions.text: A naked man is caught in his room who has installed hidden camera in a neighbour’s room who is an 18 year old girl, and peeping into her bathroom and trying to watch the female inhabitant’s bathe. This sexual perversion is defined as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Voyeurism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Voyeurism involves gaining sexual gratification by secretly observing someone without their consent, typically in private or intimate settings, such as undressing or bathing.
  • ➤ Voyeurism

questions.text: Psychological autopsy is?

options.label: A
options.text: Autopsy of brain and spinal cord

options.label: B
options.text: To inquire about the psychiatric illnesses of the deceased

options.label: C
options.text: Assessment of the mental state of deceased person before death

questions.correct_answer: C. Assessment of the mental state of deceased person before death
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Assessment of the mental state of deceased person before death

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A psychological autopsy is used to assess the mental and emotional state of a deceased person before death, especially in cases of suicide , to understand the factors that may have led to the death. It involves reviewing the deceased’s history, interviewing relevant people, and examining records.
  • ➤ psychological autopsy
  • ➤ mental and emotional state
  • ➤ suicide

questions.text: During a high-profile court case, the jury is presented with the situation of a 40-year-old university professor who has been charged with the serious assault of a colleague. It comes to light during the trial that the professor has been battling untreated schizophrenia, characterized by profound auditory hallucinations and delusions. On the day in question, he was under the delusion that his colleague was a covert agent sent to harm him, leading to the assault. The defence argues that the professor's mental state at the time of the incident rendered him incapable of understanding his actions' nature or distinguishing right from wrong. Given these circumstances and applying the Legal Test of Insanity, how should the professor's criminal responsibility be assessed?

options.label: A
options.text: He is criminally responsible because he was conscious of his physical actions during the assault.

options.label: B
options.text: He is not criminally responsible due to his inability to comprehend the true nature of his actions because of his delusional perception.

options.label: C
options.text: He is not criminally responsible due to his inability to control his actions due to his underlying schizophrenia.

options.label: D
options.text: He is criminally responsible because his mental illness does not excuse violent behavior.

questions.correct_answer: B. He is not criminally responsible due to his inability to comprehend the true nature of his actions because of his delusional perception.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) He is not criminally responsible due to his inability to comprehend the true nature of his actions because of his delusional perception.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of insanity defense , the key factor is whether the individual was able to understand the nature of their actions and distinguish between right and wrong at the time of the offense. Delusions that distort a person’s perception of reality, as in this case, can render them not criminally responsible under the M'Naghten Rule .
  • ➤ insanity defense
  • ➤ understand the nature of their actions
  • ➤ right and wrong
  • ➤ not criminally responsible
  • ➤ M'Naghten Rule

questions.text: In a rural clinic, a medical officer is faced with a case of acute poisoning. A 25-year-old patient has been brought in after ingesting an unknown substance at home. The medical officer needs to quickly administer an initial treatment to reduce the absorption of the poison. In preparing an emergency response, the medical officer considers the components of the universal antidote. Which of the following substances, commonly available in medical settings, is a part of this universal antidote and should be administered in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Activated charcoal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of acute poisoning , especially when the substance is unknown, activated charcoal is the key component of the universal antidote and is effective in reducing the absorption of many toxic substances.
  • ➤ acute poisoning
  • ➤ activated charcoal
  • ➤ universal antidote

questions.text: A 6-year-old child comes to casualty with history of unknown poisoning by some seed/drug. On examination patient has dilated pupils, dry mouth, delirium and decreased secretions with hallucination. What poisoning should the doctor suspect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dhatura

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize the symptoms of anticholinergic poisoning , including dilated pupils, dry mouth, and delirium. Dhatura poisoning is a classic example of anticholinergic toxicity and should be suspected in such cases.
  • ➤ anticholinergic poisoning
  • ➤ Dhatura poisoning

questions.text: Identify the active principle of the plant shown below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hyoscine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize Datura and understand that its active principles include atropine , hyoscyamine , and hyoscine , all of which have strong anticholinergic effects. These alkaloids are responsible for the toxic effects associated with Datura poisoning.
  • ➤ Datura
  • ➤ atropine
  • ➤ hyoscyamine
  • ➤ hyoscine

questions.text: A 7-year-old child from an environment presents with pallor, fatigue, and abdominal discomfort. Laboratory investigations reveal a hemoglobin level of 9.5 g/dL and a peripheral blood smear demonstrates a peculiar finding shown below. Which of the following differential diagnoses is most likely responsible for this finding in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Viral infection affecting erythropoiesis, causing aberrant RNA synthesis.

options.label: B
options.text: Lead poisoning leading to abnormal iron metabolism, leading to intracellular iron accumulation within red blood cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, caused by the production of autoantibodies against red blood cell antigens.

options.label: D
options.text: Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.

questions.correct_answer: D. Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize basophilic stippling as a key feature of lead poisoning , resulting from the disruption of heme synthesis and the accumulation of ribosomal material in red blood cells. This is important in diagnosing children exposed to lead, which can lead to significant anemia and other systemic effects.
  • ➤ basophilic stippling
  • ➤ lead poisoning
  • ➤ ribosomal material

questions.text: Which of the following chelating agents is recommended for acute Lead poisoning with signs of encephalopathy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Dimercaprol + Calcium EDTA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that in acute lead poisoning with encephalopathy , the combination of Dimercaprol (BAL) and Calcium EDTA is the most effective treatment. Dimercaprol removes lead from the brain, while Calcium EDTA clears it from the blood and other tissues.
  • ➤ acute lead poisoning with encephalopathy
  • ➤ Dimercaprol (BAL)
  • ➤ Calcium EDTA
  • ➤ Dimercaprol
  • ➤ Calcium EDTA

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to ED in a coma with CPR in progress. A friend found him in the schoolyard. His friend confesses that the patient has been depressed over the past several days. His initial labs reveal hypocalcemia and a severe metabolic acidosis. The urine shows calcium oxalate crystals. What was the toxic ingestion?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ethylene Glycol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize that the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine, along with hypocalcemia and severe metabolic acidosis , is highly indicative of ethylene glycol poisoning . This condition requires immediate medical intervention due to its life-threatening effects.
  • ➤ calcium oxalate crystals
  • ➤ hypocalcemia
  • ➤ severe metabolic acidosis
  • ➤ ethylene glycol poisoning

questions.text: An approximately twenty-something year old female presents to the emergency department after she collapsed outside a bar. Physical Examination: T: 97.5°F HR: 60 bpm RR: 5 breaths per minute BP: 75/57 mm Hg Pupils are miotic but equal. Pulmonary: Clear to auscultation. CV: Regular rate and rhythm. Abdomen: Normal Neurologic: GCS = 6 (E1V1M4). Best treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Naloxone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected opioid overdose, characterized by respiratory depression, miotic pupils, and decreased consciousness, Naloxone is the first-line treatment. It is an opioid antagonist that works rapidly to reverse opioid effects, particularly life-threatening respiratory depression.
  • ➤ Naloxone

questions.text: A substance abuser was found on the roadside with low respiratory rate and with pinpoint pupils. Which of the following should be suspected in this drug abuser?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Morphine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hallmark signs of opioid poisoning, including respiratory depression, miosis, and CNS depression. The treatment of choice in an emergency setting for opioid overdose is Naloxone, which rapidly reverses these life-threatening symptoms.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with agitation, dilated pupils, and tachycardia. He appears restless and paranoid, and he is sweating profusely. His blood pressure is elevated. What is the likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute Cocaine poisoning

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize the hallmark signs of acute cocaine poisoning , which include agitation , dilated pupils , tachycardia , and elevated blood pressure , due to its powerful stimulant effects on the central nervous system and cardiovascular system.
  • ➤ acute cocaine poisoning
  • ➤ agitation
  • ➤ dilated pupils
  • ➤ tachycardia
  • ➤ elevated blood pressure

questions.text: Activated charcoal is ineffective in poisoning of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ethyl alcohol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should remember that activated charcoal is ineffective for substances such as ethyl alcohol, metals, hydrocarbons, and corrosives. For poisoning with these substances, other treatment methods are required.

questions.text: A Casualty medical officer is called to assess a patient who has ingested a toxic substance. During the assessment, the medical officer observes that the patient's urine has turned green. This unusual symptom raises concerns about the specific toxic substance involved. Which toxic substance is most likely responsible for the green-colored urine seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Phenol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize that green-colored urine is a distinguishing feature of phenol (carbolic acid) poisoning , and they should be aware of other associated symptoms to confirm the diagnosis in such cases.
  • ➤ green-colored urine
  • ➤ phenol (carbolic acid) poisoning

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with symptoms of poisoning. He is conscious but in distress, and reports ingesting a substance about an hour ago. The medical officer notes a distinct smell from the patient's breath. Considering the nature of the substance ingested and the time since ingestion, the medical officer must decide on the appropriate decontamination procedure. For which of the following poisons, consistent with the patient's presentation, is gastric lavage particularly indicated?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Carbolic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that gastric lavage is contraindicated in most corrosive poisonings except in specific cases like carbolic acid poisoning, where it can be performed cautiously due to the formation of a hard, leathery coating in the stomach.
  • ➤ gastric lavage
  • ➤ carbolic acid

questions.text: A person was brought to emergency with history of snake bite 8 hours ago. The patient had low respiratory rate and bradycardia with drooping of eyelids noted. 10 vials of antivenom were administered. What is the next line of management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Give atropine + neostigmine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize that atropine and neostigmine are used as adjunctive therapy in neurotoxic snake bites, particularly in cases with neuromuscular weakness and respiratory depression, following the administration of antivenom.
  • ➤ atropine and neostigmine

questions.text: After visiting a village temple with his grandmother, a 5-year-old boy began crying intensely during the return trip. Within three hours, he was brought to the emergency department. He displayed symptoms such as altered consciousness, cold and sweaty extremities, heightened salivation, and excessive sweating. Physical examination revealed paleness and priapism, along with vital signs as follows: blood pressure of 140/78 mmHg, heart rate of 152 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 36 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. Considering his condition, what treatment approach would you choose for his management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Prazosin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize that prazosin is the treatment of choice for scorpion envenomation , as it counteracts the excessive sympathetic stimulation caused by the venom. The classic presentation includes tachycardia , hypertension , excessive salivation , and priapism .
  • ➤ prazosin
  • ➤ scorpion envenomation
  • ➤ tachycardia
  • ➤ hypertension
  • ➤ excessive salivation
  • ➤ priapism

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual presents to the emergency department with severe pain, restlessness, hypertension, tachycardia, and sweating after being stung by a scorpion. The sting site is red and swollen, with no signs of necrosis. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Apply a tourniquet proximal to the sting site

options.label: D
options.text: Cleanse the wound and apply ice packs

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Administer prazosin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that prazosin is the treatment of choice in scorpion envenomation presenting with systemic symptoms like hypertension , tachycardia , and excessive sweating , as it helps to alleviate the effects of sympathetic overactivity caused by the venom.
  • ➤ prazosin
  • ➤ scorpion envenomation
  • ➤ hypertension
  • ➤ tachycardia
  • ➤ excessive sweating

questions.text: A middle aged man from West Bengal presents with paraesthesia of hands and feet, hyperkeratosis, lines in the nails and rain drop pigmentation in the hands. The most likely causative toxin for the above-mentioned symptoms is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arsenic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize that chronic arsenic poisoning is associated with skin changes like hyperkeratosis , Mees' lines , and raindrop pigmentation , along with neurological symptoms such as paraesthesia . This is especially relevant in regions known for arsenic contamination, such as West Bengal .
  • ➤ chronic arsenic poisoning
  • ➤ hyperkeratosis
  • ➤ Mees' lines
  • ➤ raindrop pigmentation
  • ➤ paraesthesia
  • ➤ West Bengal

questions.text: A patient was brought to casualty with seizures. He had multiple episodes and was taking herbal medicines for the same. He was conscious in between the episodes. During the episodes, he had arching of his back. What is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Strychnine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize that strychnine poisoning presents with opisthotonus , conscious seizures , and intense muscle spasms, which are distinct features that help in diagnosing this toxic exposure.
  • ➤ strychnine poisoning
  • ➤ opisthotonus
  • ➤ conscious seizures

questions.text: Identify the plant shown in the image below and the condition it is responsible for?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ergot Poisoning

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize that ergot poisoning arises from consuming rye or other grains infected by the fungus Claviceps purpurea , and it can result in severe vasoconstrictive and neurologic symptoms.
  • ➤ ergot poisoning
  • ➤ rye
  • ➤ Claviceps purpurea

questions.text: What is the active principle of the poison shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bhilawanol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should be able to recognize the marking nut ( Semecarpus anacardium ) and understand that its active toxic principle is bhilawanol , which can cause toxic reactions upon exposure.
  • ➤ marking nut
  • ➤ Semecarpus anacardium
  • ➤ bhilawanol

questions.text: A 28-year-old male arrives in the emergency department after being exposed to an unidentified toxic substance given to him by a friend. His symptoms include dry mouth, urinary retention, and constipation. During the examination, his pulse rate is recorded at 140 beats per minute, and his pupils are observed to be dilated. Which substance is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Belladona

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize that Belladonna poisoning produces anticholinergic symptoms such as dry mouth, dilated pupils, tachycardia, urinary retention, and constipation. This presentation helps differentiate it from other toxic substances like opioids or organophosphates.
  • ➤ Belladonna poisoning
  • ➤ anticholinergic symptoms
